opener.dateline:
J.W. Carr Esqre
164 Frognell Hampstead Friday morng. April 1st. 1819

div.p:
Here we are this delicious spring day
in the midst of spring delights and
in the midst of the far greater delights
of a family happy as our own once
was and united as they were & are & I hope
ever will be - Thanks to you - mother
in law of four families- a higher title
to respect than mother of any FatimiaFatimah
sultan or emperor that ever existed

How people can be so very kind to us
as they are I cannot conceive. After be-
ing being at Byrkley Lodge I was surprised
to find that we could meet with
such friendship in a person who was
no ways connected with us as
was shown to us by Lady E Whitbread
- House - servants - carriage - advice
sympathy every thing that her warm
heart could give was ours. - We thought
we should be miserable in the change
on leaving her. But the Hopes were so
very good in that way that we were
happy there and in the midst of their
magnificence quite domesticated -
Then coming here afterwards was de-
lightful delightful - After all, what is comfortable
in a house and home is far preferable
to the utmost grandeur & magnificence -
- By candle-light, splendidly lighted up
and filled with Dukes & Duchess's &c &c
that house of Mr. Hope's is festive & fit for gala nights;
but by day the size and gilding of the
rooms & the company look of all the
furniture & the want of comfortable
little ordinary tables that you can
use without scruple prevent the feeling
of comfort and enjoyment such as
we have been used to. - When I one day
said to Mr. Hope "I am really afraid to
put my writing desk down on these
beautiful inlaid tables. He answered
"write on the wood of that table if you
"please & I shall be glad of it " - Yet still
there was a feeling that prevented comfort.

The moment we came here we
felt at home completely & mixed with
the every day habits of the family - I
never saw a family that would suit
better with our own - I long for you & all
my sisters and Lovell to know them as
we do. Some time or other I hope this
will be -

Saturday morng.morning
April 2d.

How very fortunate we were in coming
here yesterday - for my dear Fanny's sake
particularly. She had been at a French
play the night before we left Town and
caught cold (She swears she had a cough before) - She had a headache the next
morning & as soon as she had drank tea
Private
165 here she went to bed. She was so hot &
feverish in the night that and coughed
so much that I determined as I told her in the middle of the night the next morn
tho' she laughed at me for it to send
for a physician - Before morning came
the burning heat went off and a circum
stancecircumstance happened that made me hope
she would be materially better. Never
thelessNevertheless I determined to send for a physi-
cian physician - Baillie whom I should have
preferred as an older man, could not
be had - gone to Windsor & as Joanna
who came to breakfast told me he would
not come down here except in a case
of life or death for any mortal - So I
sent for Dr. Holland - and explaining
all the circumstances of her health to
good motherly Mrs. Carr we settled
before Dr. H came that it would be so
disagreeable to F to mention all the
circumstances to him that we should
only state a cold - & trust to nature who
had taken this favorable turn in the
interval - However when Dr. H came
he took me out to walk & asked every
possible question - This F does not know
- I am rather glad now the disagreeable
moment is over that he is not prescribing
on half knowledge - He gave her the night
before last two doses of antimony -
advised a blister on her chest if the pain
continued - But it did not continue &
I would not put on the blister - She perspired
happily at night - much better tho
weak & feverish all day.

Her mind has been too much
harrassed. It was very painful to her
to give LW so much pain as she has
been forced to give him. We breakfast
ed in Harley St. the morning before
we came here & she had a long confer
ence conference with him in the front drawing
room. He was very anxious to come
here during this week. Fanny thought
it better that he should not - He shewed great
emotion I believe cried bitterly - But
she suffered much. It was settled howe-
ver however that he should not come - He behav
very handsomely & told me he was quite
convinced that Fanny is left to her own
inclinations & her own unbiassed judgment

He followed me down stairs & trembling
& pale as milk took my hands & faultered
out - "Tho' I know - according to my engage-
"ment engagement - & your explanations I am not
"to take any thing kind for encouragement
"- yet I cannot help thanking you for your
"good nature to me. "

I do pity him exceedingly - and esteem
him too - he has by his own conduct
raised himself high in my opinion -
- I wish him all good. But I cannot
wish that Fanny's happiness shd. be sacri-
ficed sacrificed to him - Indeed the irreparable loss
of his own happiness would be the inevitable
consequence of such a vain sacrifice on
her part. She declares to me that she
feels no love for him - that she has re
-peatedly repeatedly told him so. Still he hopes
on - Since he has had a fair trial &
that such is the result of her compa-
risons comparisons & of her experience of her own
feelings I think now the refusal shd.
for his sake & hers be decisive - & that
I have as soon as it has been given
we should quit London & its neigh
borhood neighborhood - for the situation they are
now in is harrassing & cruel to them
both. I therefore decide to leave
Hampstead on the 15th. - till that day
we are engaged to Mrs. Carr & to Joanna Baillie.

On the 15th. we will return to
Kensington Gore to Lady E W - who
desired us to return to her on our
road homewards to repose after
the business should be decided - She
was very anxious that it shd. be decided
as she thought the letting it go on longer
would be disadvantageous to F in the
eyes of the world & that it wd. be said
he had been encouraged. Besides she
thought it cruel to him - for as long as
he is permitted to see her he must & will
(say what she will) nourish hope.

Then on the 15th. it is all over & we
shall be with Lady E W. - The 16th. & 17th. we
shall be there - That is till the middle of
the day on the 17th. - I have written this
morning to Mr. & Mrs. Hope to say that we
will be at the Deep Dene on the 17th. to dinner
- We can stay there 3 or 4 days - When
we are once beyond the reach of London
& out of the reach of poor L W's hopes We shall be I trust more at ease.

I had arranged things differently
- but seeing how much Fanny's health
suffered from the struggle of her mind
& the pain of giving pain or of indecision
or of ... whatever it was ... I resolved to
cut & run as fast quickly as possible - The moment
I felt assured that her real decision was
made I think thought it best they shd.
part & I hope you will think so my
dearest mother?

When I had formerly understood
that she desired more time to make
up her mind I had arranged to go to
Mr. Hopes at the Deep Dene from the 15th
to the 22d. then to return to Town to give
the 22 & 23d. to Mrs. Taddy who poor good
natured woman has been anxious be-
yond beyond conception to have us and has
invited Mc.Intosh & Lady C. Lindsay &
the Lord knows who to meet us - But
however sorry I am to disappoint
her and break my own engagement
this is but a trifle compared with
Fanny's health & happiness - and
As my dear father used to say the great
art of life is to know how to sacrifice
trifles to matters of consequence and
to know what are trifles compared
with great objects. I shall write to
Mrs. Taddy to state that some circum stances circumstances have occurred which render
it absolutely necessary that we shd.
leave London immediately - and
I am sure in saying this I speak truth
- for I do think it absolutely necessary
for dear Fan's health & peace of mind
- She said the other day ."I am quite
afraid of being touched by the feelings of
the moment of pity for him & being led to
sacrifice my happiness & his "- and
another time, she said

"I know I shall be teized into mar
"rying marrying this man at last"

You talk my dearest mother of
your own indecision - But if you could
know the agony of indecision I have
been in these last days you would feel
yourself quite resolute compared with me
- Every change I saw in Fanny made me
fear that I was mistaking her mind and
doing wrong either by him or by her - you
know how contradictory & inconsistent
the human heart is in certain circum-
stances circumstances . Sometimes F would say

"But I am giving up so much - such
a noble generous character - I am sure
I never shall be loved so much by any
body else -"

Then why refuse him - This ground
gone over & over again in every possible
light alternately frightened and reassured
me and at last ... that is at this moment
I feel convinced that I see & that she sees
to the bottom of her own heart - and that
there is no love lurking there - Her esteem
for him has been encreased by his conduct
latterly - by his integrity & generosity &
wonderful power over himself - But
the love, the first love which
was
raised before there had been opportunity
of comparison has completely b vanished
in consequence I believe of the comparisons
& reflexions she has had time & oppor
tunity opportunity fully to make - She feels that he
is not a companion fit for her - no litera
ture literature no powers of conversation and tho
his manners might be polished up tolerable
so as to pass in society yet habits would recur
- and his then his family & connexions
Though he says his wife should not be
forced to live with them how can cd. it be
otherwise without his breaking all his
family ties & old intimacies . This wd.
make him both despicable & unhappy
- It must end by his wife's sinking to
their level in society & to their m habits of
mind. This Fanny feels & she knows
that this would render her miserable
- God forbid she shd.should be so sacrificed.

Your brother Francis behaves with
all the candor & impartiality that cd.
be expected from his character. He
must be sorry for his friend. But he
never advocates his cause. Fanny
has been left by him entirely to her
own decision - He now agrees with
me that they shd.should separate as soon as
possible -

I fear I have been saying the same
things over & over 100 times. But you will
excuse it - my mind is so full of these
thoughts it is a relief to me to pour them
out to you dear mother - the person in
the world who can sympathise most
in my indecisions -

Monday morng.
Sunday she was much better - did not
come to dinner - eat only bread pudding
and orange - Captn. B came over to see
her & spent the greater part of the morning
talking
To her as she lay in bed -

Mr. & Mrs. & Miss Binnion (Sunderland Binnion)
in the evening - and at dinner - She has
a nasty affected company -voice- & manner
& I was tired to death of her .- Tho they
all said that Fanny whom they saw
at tea in the drawing room sitting in the dark
was beautiful -

She coughed much all sunday night &
lay awake dear soul endeavoring that
I should not hear her. - The circumstance
on which I had depended for the mate
-rial material improvement of her health stopped
- I wrote again at 6 o clock in the morning
to Dr. Holland desiring to see him again
to day. sent the note by Mr. Carr who
goes went early to Town - Fanny has
taken a good dose of castor oil this
morning - is much better - still in bed
- Miss Carr has been sitting beside her
reading Rose's letters from Italy which
have amused her while I have been
scribbling this at the foot of her bed -
I expect Dr. H every minute - I must
now go down to luncheon

All that I have written I know is a heap
of confusion - But so much the better - it will
be to you a most true picture of my mind -
If you were with us you could know no more
Little Francis was with us from saturday
2 o clock till Sunday evening when I sent
him to his Charter House in one of the Camp
stead coaches with George B inside passenger
along with him - It is but a very short walk
from the place where that coach puts up to
the Charter H. And George is now grown so
bright that he could accomplish that much -
you know Fannymust be within the Charter H.
walls by 9 o clock at night - He was in time
This mode of conveyance is very convenient
& cheap - only 3/6- for both Francisis liked and
loved by all who see him - and lucky
little dog little cuckoo that he is! he gets into the beds
of the sons of the families just the moment
they vacate them. For instance at Lady E
W's the very day her son left home Fran
cis
Francis
had his bed - the very day after we
came here Mrs. Carrs son went to Cambridge
& there was his bed ready for Francis
to pop into that night - Mr. and Mrs. Carr
& Miss Carr & the Harrow-boy the 3d. son
of his family are all delighted with
Francis: they say they never saw so in-
-telligent intelligent good and gentlemanlike a
little boy. We heard this opinion given
of him too by one of his schoolfellows who
did not know that "little Edgeworth" was
anything to us .- I have written to Mr.
Watkinson to inquire whether the boys
are to have any Easter Holidays - If they
are to be allowed Franciscomes with his
uncle on thursday to dine with Joanna
Baillie & us - & Fannywill stay with us till
the tuesday following - This is the most delight
12 ful delightful house & family for him to be in - full
of literature and information & books &
Museum
with proper mixture of bodily exercise
& family nonsense & open hearted
affection such as he is used to at home
- I am sure that when we are far away
Mr. and Mrs. Carr will have him here
often & be kind to him. This thought will
be a great comfort to me & to Fanny when I am part
ing from him poor fellow!

I send Lovell a pamphlet & notes
Dr. Roget left for him - I will send in a
day or two a biographical notice he has sent me of
Sir S.Samuel Romilly -

Give my love to Sophy I enclose two Parisian
visiting tickets elegant enough for her.
I forgot to tell you that we had seen
Lord Carrington - very kind but much older
in appearance & much depressed in spirits
- He says he will come & see us here or
will manage somehow that we shall
meet - I wish it might be at High Wy-
combe Wycombe
in our way homewards.

I have seen Hunter lately . Have
agreed to give him the whole of the Ms.manuscripts
in Sepr.September- He is to send me over the proof
sheets. That operation will retard the
publication but is in my opinion quite
necessary. He means to have it out by Xmass
- The first part vol is now going to press!-
Thank you & L for Mr. Days picture - Say
when it sets out - direct it & Lord L's to 31 Harley St.
Fanny is so nursed and so loved by
all this family that you would be delighted
with them as I am. So far from being any
trouble to them I am sure it is a pleasure
to them to do all they do for her & they
will like her all the better for the kind-
ness they shew her. Mrs. Carr is the most
kind hearted motherly creature I have
seen since I came to England - How fortu
-nate fortunate we were to come here just at the
moment we did. We have a deightful
airy bedchamber with chearful bow win-
dow window - large bed for Fanny & me - a room
adjoining for Honora & a little dressing
room - with a double door & tiny anteroom
that shuts out all noise - As Mrs. Carr says
I am sure these 3 rooms were intended
from the Creation for the 3 Edgeworths they
fit & suit them so exactly.

Mr. Carr - Oh mother I almost envy
these dear good girls the happiness of
the affection they have for their father
- If you could see them all from the eldest
to the youngest running to the gate to
meet him as he rides home on his white
horse!- He is one of the very happiest
men I ever saw - of the happiest temper
- working hard all day, usefully & hono
rably honorably & coming home every evening to
such a happy cultivated united family
- When he sits down to dinner in the midst
of his children he says he throws aside
every care for the remainder of the day & enjoys
himself - He is passionately fond of draw
ing and music & one daughter draws
admirably & another plays & sings ad-
mirably admirably - and all their accomplishments
are for him & for their own family.

They are really happy people - Certain-
ly Fanny has had the advantage of
seeing a greater variety of the insides
of families of all ranks than could
have been expected.- even by my san-
guine sanguine imagination

I enclose two paragraphs which
appeared in the Times - Perhaps they
might never strike your eye if you
were not aware that Mr. Carr is Solr. to the
Excise - These paragraphs will shew
you how high he stands in public esti-
mation estimation .

Dr. Wollaston dines here tomorrow & I
have leave to ask Captn. B. to dine to
meet him - Many of them whose names
I cannot recollect are expected - If Fan
ny
Fanny
is well we shall be happy.

I cant wait to see Dr. H. he is
so late - Fanny is better & drinking arrow root - keep your
mind easy - I will write again tomorrow
